title: 111_hr2667
content: The "Early Support for Families Act" establishes grants to states for quality home visitation programs for families with young children and families expecting children. This Act aims to support quality home visitation programs for these families. The purpose of this section is to improve the well-being of children by establishing quality home visitation programs for families with young children and those expecting. States must submit a grant application that includes a description of the programs, intended outcomes, evidence of effectiveness, and results of a needs assessment. The curr_chunk discusses the implementation of home visitation programs for families with young children and those expecting children in the State. It includes details on the number of eligible families receiving services, funding sources, gaps in services, and training activities. The State must provide assurances to prioritize serving communities in high need, especially those with low-income families or high child maltreatment rates. The State must reserve 5 percent of grant funds for training and technical assistance for home visitation programs. Coordination with other child and family services, health services, and income supports is promoted. Referrals to other programs for children and families should be provided when appropriate. Compliance with subsection (i) and cooperation with evaluations is required. Additional information may be requested by the Secretary. The Secretary shall allot funds to Indian tribes and States based on the number of children from families with income below 200 percent of the poverty line. The Secretary allots funds to Indian tribes and States based on the number of children from families below 200 percent of the poverty line. States must reserve 5 percent of grant funds for training and technical assistance for home visitation programs. Reallotments are available if a State does not expend its allotment. States must maintain effort by spending on quality home visitation programs for families with young children. Grants are made to each State by the Secretary. The Secretary grants funds to States based on eligible expenditures for home visitation programs, with a reimbursable percentage defined for each fiscal year. Eligible expenditures include voluntary home visitation services. Expenditures for voluntary home visitation programs must adhere to evidence-based models, employ trained staff, and provide linkages to community resources. Expenditures for home visitation programs must adhere to evidence-based models and prioritize funding for programs with the strongest evidence of effectiveness. Funding for programs that do not meet this criteria will not be considered eligible expenditures to the extent that they exceed the applicable percentage of the State's allotment for the fiscal year. The State must provide a matching percentage for home visitation program grants, starting at 55 percent in 2011 and decreasing to 40 percent in 2014. Federal funds cannot be used to meet the State's share of costs. The Secretary has the authority to waive or modify certain provisions for Indian tribes if compliance would be burdensome. The State must submit annual reports on the progress of programs funded by grants, detailing services, program characteristics, provider qualifications, recipient demographics, program costs, and outcomes. The evaluation of home visitation programs funded under this section will assess their impact on child and parent outcomes, including child maltreatment, health, development, and school readiness. It will also examine the effectiveness of these programs on different populations. The ability of programs to improve outcomes varies across programs and populations. Reports to Congress include an interim report within 2 years and a final report within 4 years. Annual reports to Congress detail high need communities targeted, service delivery models, and program characteristics. The evaluation of home visitation programs funded under this section will assess program characteristics, outcomes, research-based instruction, training activities, costs, and monitoring methods. $10,000,000 is reserved for evaluation costs. The Secretary is appropriated funds for evaluation, training, and technical assistance for early childhood home visitation programs, including grants to Indian tribes. The appropriations for fiscal years 2010-2014 are specified, totaling $2 billion. Indian tribes are treated as states for the purposes of this section.
